thread.title: Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact
thread.title_full: Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact

title: Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact
text:
Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact Iowa State added its fourth basketball commit for 2016 in 6-4 guard Jakolby Long from Mustang, Okla. Post to Facebook Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact Iowa State added its fourth basketball commit for 2016 in 6-4 guard Jakolby Long from Mustang, Okla. Check out this story on desmoinesregister.com: http://dmreg.co/1Lm9kH9 Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 1 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Oklahoma guard commits to ISU hoops, expects immediate impact Chris Cuellar , ccuellar@dmreg.com 1:52 p.m. CDT October 9, 2015 Iowa State University 482 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Jakolby Long has gotten used to playing and winning. 
The Mustang, Okla., prep basketball prospect plans to do both right away next year at Iowa State. 
The 6-foot-4 three-star combo guard committed to coach Steve Prohm and the Cyclones on Friday, one week after visiting Ames and deciding he wanted to crack the lineup. 
"Hopefully I'll play 20 minutes-plus and maybe start as a freshman," Long told the Register. 
"If I come in and keep playing the way I'm playing now, I'll probably be able to start and that really was one of the big benefits to me committing to Iowa State." 
Long says Prohm's staff started contacting him over the summer and extended a scholarship offer following July's Nike Peach Jam. ISU assistant T.J. Otzelberger led the recruitment against more than a dozen Division I offers, including Oklahoma State, Kansas State, Wichita State, Missouri, Ole Miss, Houston, South Carolina and Texas Tech. 
"I really didn't care about staying close to home or not, but when I decided to go to Iowa State I knew it would be a good fit for me and close enough for my family to watch me play," Long said. 
"My dad (Terry Long) told me not to pick a school because of its status, pick a school because you love a place and want to live there." 
As a junior, Long led Mustang High School to an undefeated state championship season with his father serving as head coach. He averaged 15 points, eight rebounds and six assists on a balanced team that rolled through Class 6A, Oklahoma's largest classification. — wizard kelly (@jsnipe43) October 9, 2015 
Football was another college option for the Athletes First AAU product, but Long has decided to put his explosive 210-pound frame to use on Big 12 basketball courts. 
"I love Iowa State's style of play," he said. 
"They shoot a lot of threes, they play aggressive defense, they get out and run and that's the style I want to play for." 
Rivals.com had Long ranked in its top 150 players nationally last year, and Scout.com currently lists him as the top-ranked prep player in Oklahoma. Iowa State lands Jakolby Long out of Oklahoma. Son of a coach, well built and physical scorer. — Eric Bossi (@ebosshoops) October 9, 2015 
"Long ran the point, played off the wing and also spent some time in the paint," Rivals analyst Eric Bossi wrote after a Mustang win in Texas last season. 
"Wherever he was, Long showed strength and toughness. A high-energy player with a great feel for the game, he got his team off to a quick start with the three-ball before making plays as they were needed down the stretch." 
Long is the fourth commitment to Prohm's 2016 class, following guard Donovan Jackson (Iowa Western Community College), forward Solomon Young (Sacramento, Calif.), and wing Emmanuel Malou (Yuba Community College). 
Skipping over nearby Oklahoma and Oklahoma State could raise a few eyebrows, but Long expects to see his Oklahoma City metro rivals when Big 12 play comes around. 
"It's a different pick from most people that live in my state, but I think I'll be fine. Iowa State's a great place," Long said. 482 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://dmreg.co/1Lm9kH9 TOP VIDEOS
